messageBody:
Inanc,

I like the old mantra "test until fear turns to boredom". Sounds like
you've reached the boredom point. One thing worth discussing as a
team is if you've already tested everything that could possibly go
wrong. For example, imagine that you're collecting a customer's
payment information, and want to test the software's behavior when the
payment information is rejected. Further, it could be rejected
because:

- The credit card number is invalid
- The card has expired
- The card address does not match the address given

If I was starting to get bored, I'd probably test all of these
scenarios with unit or functional tests, and just one with a UI test,
figuring that if all those tests worked, the odds would be low that UI
tests of the other scenarios would reveal new information.

Does this make sense?

David

On Fri, Nov 13, 2009 at 11:55 AM, Inanc Gumus <inanc.gumus@...> wrote:
> There is a library which contains service/domain/infrastructure layers. That library's outcomes is used by the presentation layer which is written in another programming language.
>
> We'r functionally testing the library. Also, we'r testing the UI through interaction tests.
>
> But, we've found that, we'r writing the same scenarios and expectations for those tests. If we try to reuse the scenarios this adds to the obscurity of tests. Or the reverse is duplication of the scenarios.
>
> Do you have recommendation about how can we reuse the same scenarios both for functional and interaction tests that are separate environments?
